Getting used to the idea of “less but better” may prove hard.  

We have been rewarded in the past for doing more and more.  

Yet, at a certain point, more effort causes our progress to stall.  

The idea of a direct correlation between results and effort is appealing.  

It seems fair.  

Yet research across many fields paints a different picture.  

Most people have heard of the “Pareto Principle.”  

This idea was introduced by Vilfredo Pareto in the 1790s.  

It states that 20 percent of our efforts produce 80 percent of results.  

In 1951, Joseph Moses Juran expanded on this idea.  

He called it “the Law of the Vital Few.”  

His observation was that resolving a tiny fraction of problems improves quality.  

He found a willing test audience for this idea in Japan.  

Japan had a poor reputation for producing low-cost, low-quality goods.  

By focusing on a few vital improvements, he changed perceptions.  

The phrase “made in Japan” took on a new meaning.  

The quality revolution led to Japan’s rise as a global economic power.  

Distinguishing the “trivial many” from the “vital few” applies to all endeavors.  

Richard Koch has persuasively applied the Pareto Principle in his books.  

Indeed, the examples are everywhere.  

Think of Warren Buffett.  

He has famously said, “Our investment philosophy borders on lethargy.”  

He means he and his firm make relatively few investments.  

They keep these investments for a long time.  

In The Tao of Warren Buffett, Mary Buffett and David Clark explain this.  

Warren decided early in his career to make fewer investment decisions.  

He chose to invest only in businesses he was sure of.  

He bet heavily on those businesses.  

He owes 90% of his wealth to just ten investments.  

Sometimes, what you don’t do is as important as what you do.  

In short, he makes big bets on essential investment opportunities.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The concept of "less but better" emphasizes that focusing on a few vital efforts can lead to significantly greater results than trying to do more.
